The Cabinet continued the discussion whichhad been begun on the morning o^ the same day on thesubject of the Budget for 1929-30.The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasury was present for a short time to give information regard-ing the legislative programme for the remainder ofthe Session. It transpired that, by means of certainreadjustments of the programme^ time could be found for the enactment of certain legislation requiredin connection with one of the Chancellor of theExchequer's proposals, and this proposal was accord-ingly adopted, subject to a modification necessitated by administrative considerations.On one point of principle, on which theChancellor of the Exchequer had asked for the viswsof his colleagues, every member of the Cabinet present was ashed to express his opinion, and the Chancellorof the Exchequer undertook to examine the quiestionfurther in the light of the Cabinet discussion before taking his final decision.Subject to this point and to the matter mentionedin the following Conclusion, the Cabinet approved generally the proposals of the Chancellor of theExchequer.In view of the great importance of secrecy, thedetails of the Budget, in accordance with precedent,are not recorded in the Cabinet Minutes,/ sIMPERIALPREFERENCE .The Needs ofthe west indies .(previous reference:Cabinet 17(86), Con-conclusion 1.)3. In the course of the discussion referred toin the previous Conclusion, the Secretary of Statefor the Colonies, as a matter of urgency, broughtto the attention of the Cabinet the great distresswhich had arisen in certain Colonies, more particu-larly the West Indies and Mauritius, owing to thefall in the price of sugar. This fall was purelyartificial,' being due to a price war between com-competing interests, the effects of which had reactedto the detriment of our Colonies, so far, in thecase of Mauritius, as to necessitate a loan toenable next year's crop to be planted. Mr Amerymade a strong appeal for an increase in the imperial preference on sugar, in order to alleviate thedistress in the Colori;e3 concerned.The Cabinet agreed That a Cabinet Committee, composed asfollows -The President of the Board of Trade(In the Chair),The Secretary of State for Scotland,The Minister of Health,The Minister of Labour,-should meet with the Secretary of Statefor the Colonies, the Minister ofAgriculture and Fisheries, and theChairman of the Board of customs and Excise, at 10 a.m. on the follow-ing morning, in the Room of theSecretary of State for the Colonies,for the purpose of considering andadvising the Cabinet as to whetherthe emergency in the Colonies was such as to render it desirable togive in the forthcoming Budget anincreased measure of Imperial Prefer-ence on Sugar. 4. Arising out of the Budget discussion,preliminary consideration was given to the questionof the general policy of the Government, in thecourse of which, among other questions, reference was made to SLUM CLEARANCE, MATERNITY AND child welfare, EDUCATION, AGRICULTURAL POLICY, IMPERIALDEVELOPMENT.The Prime Minister Intimated that the discussionmight be resumed at a Meeting to be held on thefollowing day .
